Award.AwardTitle: The Third Computing Innovation Fellows Project

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: The Nation?s universities and industrial research labs are facing continuing budgetary pressures as a result of the economic downturn. The aim of this project is to forestall a permanent loss of research talent that is likely to occur if new computer science PhDs are forced to seek employment outside the field due to hiring reductions brought about by the current economic situation. The NSF Computing Innovation Fellows (CIFellows) project will enable approximately twenty new PhDs in the computing fields to develop the additional credentials and experience to make them more effective researchers and/or teachers. This is the third year of the CIFellows program, which has already supported a total of 107 Fellows in one- to two-year positions at academic institutions and industrial labs across the country. The selection process will actively seek applications from women and people from underrepresented groups; it will also identify candidates for awards from a cross-section of institutions. As a result, a broad range of institutions will strengthen their research groups and labs, thereby, improving the national infrastructure and research workforce in computer science, allied fields and corresponding application domains.

POR.DRECONTENT:
CI Fellows (1136996) Project Outcomes Report

 

In early 2009, forecasts showed that the deteriorating economic climate would force a large number of new Ph.D.s in computer science and related fields to delay or altogether abandon a research career. Projected Ph.D. production was high, and jobs in academia and industry were few. Leaders of the computing research community feared a cohort of able researchers would be permanently lost to the profession. With encouragement from the National Science Foundation?s (NSF) Directorate for Computer Science and Engineering (CISE), the Computing Community Consortium (CCC) proposed to develop and administer a short-term program that would provide postdoctoral positions ? called Computing Innovation Fellows, or CIFellows for short with the intention of pairing postdocs with a designated mentor to help them through the transition between getting their PhDs and moving into computing research and teaching positions.

The CI Fellow program[1] was announced on May 15, 2009 and two committees, made up of 35 leading research from academia and industry, were recruited to steer the program and review applications. By the application deadline of June 9, over 1,200 mentors had signed up and 522 applications were completed, generating 945 separate applicant-mentor pairings. On July 8, CCC announced the selection of the 60 initial CIFellows. The CI Fellows program was continued in 2010 and 2011 with 47 and 20 new participants respectively. In 2014 a workshop was held in San Francisco, California that offered an opportunity for the former CIFellows to learn more about professional development from each other and dignitaries from the field.

From the initial CI Fellows grant the CCC launched the Postdoc Best Practices program[2] in April 2014. This program awarded grants to three institutions/consortia of institutions to implement best practices for strengthening the postdoc experience in computer science and computing-related fields: 1) Arizona comprised of Arizona State University, Northern Arizona University, and University of Arizona, 2) NY ASCENT made up of Columbia University, City University of New York, Cornell University, and New York University, and 3) the University of Washington. Due to program composition and numbers, each group used explored slightly different mechanisms to see which would have the greatest effect though all included some component of mentorships and skills development. Some of the methods the programs utilized include Individual Development Plans (IDPs), which offer a framework for identifying professional development needs and career objectives; workshops and seminars to develop career skills like resume writing; travel grants to attend conferences; and funding for research projects. A final report, written by CRA?s Center for Evaluating the Research Pipeline (CERP),  on the outcomes of the Postdoc program will be released soon.

In addition, the CCC used the CI Fellows grant to support several programs within the Big Data (BD) Regional Hubs[3]. Initiated in 2015 as part of NSF's Big Data program [4] the BD Regional Hubs were comprised of 4 consortia, the Northeast, Midwest, South, and West, with the goal of leading regional and grassroots partnerships in Big Data. The CCC?s funded and promoted a number of workshops and internship programs within the Hubs that were specifically designed for early career researchers to gain experience within industry and academic programs using big data.

Finally, the CCC hosted the Early Career Researcher Symposium (ECR) in Washington, DC in August 2108[5]. It brought together former CIFellows, Postdoctoral Students, and Early Career Researchers in computing and enabled participants to network and discuss emergent research visions and topics with luminaries in the field. ECR was also an opportunity for attendees to meet National Science Foundation program officers as well as representatives from other agencies. Results from the post-symposium survey indicated that overall attendees of the symposium were enthusiastic about their experience, enjoying session content and growing professionally. Furthermore, attendees found the poster session with the networking reception informative and valuable to their professional development.
